text:
I guess it's just rolling, so
I would just start whenever?
OK.
Let me gather my thoughts.

The moment that I approached my
career and my internship search

as a big question that
I wanted to answer,

it became easier to
filter through what

perhaps would be the
right opportunity
and what seemed like noise.
My career advisor--

I remember her asking me, "Well,
what are you really scared of?

What's the worst thing
that could happen?"

Honestly, it would just be
that I didn't the internship.

And so the moment
that we were really

able to reframe about what
worse looked like, it really

made me more comfortable with
the idea of taking a leap

or just learning because the
internship time is so precious.

I am interested in pursuing
entrepreneurship through

acquisition, and it's a
very long way-- supposedly--

from my pre-MBA background in
brand management at a consumer
goods company.

And so if I think about
why this leap, to me,

it's really the difference
between broad impact
and deep impact.

It really makes me think about
my dad and the family business
that he created 30 years ago.

It settled in Cameroon,
my country of origin,

and my dad was running it until
the fall of my senior year
when he very suddenly passed.

My mom has taken over
the business since.

We were able to
create opportunities

for our employees, but also,
my dad reinvested the profits

to uplift a lot of
the people living

in a town outside of my
village called Magba.

And so as I think about
launching my own firm now

and starting really full
steam ahead with my fund,

my goal is to do
for a business owner

here what my mom
has done for my dad.

So if there's a career
advice I would give,

it would actually be
to focus less on a job

and more about a
purpose or a north star

that you'd want to achieve
through your career.
And make a call.

You can change it later on,
but I find that the moment you

actually commit to
something, opportunities

can really open through
your section, your friends,

your professors,
the career office--
truly, anywhere.

But I find that sometimes, you
have to take the first step
and commit.
[MUSIC PLAYING]
